title: Do professors in college care if you show up to class? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most professors don’t even know if you’re showing up for class. There is no checklist, nobody is reading out an attendance card, it’s not any kind of required school you’ve been in. You’re paying for it, anyhow. If you want to use the service you’re paying for, that’s ultimately up to you. In my third year of mathematics, I was in upper division Linear Algebra with Ken Ribet. It’s normal to be taught by top notch mathematicians at Berkeley. That class had about 100–200 students in it. It’s likely that this wasn’t the only class that Ribet taught. It wasn’t a room. The place looked like this.  I’m fairly certain this is a picture of the exact auditorium the class was taught in. The only person that anybody recognized when absent was a student who I regarded as a genius. This student would consistently correct Ribet on his board. Ribet is a world renowned mathematician, credited for paving the way towards Andrew Wile’s proof of Fermat’s last theorem. If this student was missing, anybody would know. The room would be quiet and the faces would all look the same. For the most part, the students in these classes were studious, quiet, and hardworkers. They didn’t ask questions and mainly listened in on the lectures. In fact, anybody could simply walk in and audit the classes. On several occasions, I would notice people around 50–60 years old who were not students sitting in and taking notes. The professors didn’t care. If you were there to learn, awesome. If you were there to ask questions or correct mistakes, awesome. If you didn’t want to attend, the curve is stated on the syllabus and your grade is composed of one half midterm and one half final. This was the upper division course, too. There was a differential equations course, the last course you take in your lower division line-up. That course had something like 500 students in it. If you didn’t show up the entire semester, nobody would know. The only important thing for those classes was that your student ID was on the midterm, homework, and final.  One addendum: For most courses with a lot of students, the class gets split up into additional discussion sections. These are additional classes you take with the teacher’s assistants, or graduate students, who teach you the material in depth. These classes tend to be smaller and far more helpful than any lecture. If you didn’t attend one of those, the TA would probably notice. In fact, I would argue that it is absolutely essential to attend your discussion sections while the lecture could be viewed as supplemental. I hold this view because Berkeley, like any elite college, has a lot of professors that are busy with research or out doing activities you would expect out of a Nobel laureate. It’s not uncommon for a professor to backseat their students while pursuing research.

I am appalled by Robert Smith’s answer especially the statement that lower tier universities care but higher tier schools do and should not. My concern goes back to what we know about adult learning. Much has been written about this and I have summarized elsewhere on Quora. The core is that adults learn best when they are a) working on issues of relevance and importance to them, b) actively involved, and c) in discussions that challenge their assumptions (VABEs) about the way the world is or should be. I taught at the Harvard Business School and the Darden School at University of Virginia. We used cases and “technical notes” (summaries of current and relevant theories, not just one theoretical approach). Field cases put real business (or medical or technical or military—in use at Quantico) problems in front of students without implying a “right” answer — for many issues none exists. Coming to class ahead of time, having read and analyzed the case and theory for the class (often 3 or more a day), and participating actively in the debate with from 20–100 peers who have also read the material is central to the case method approach. Coming to class late interrupts the developing focus and energy in the room. Not coming at all hurts the absentee AND the other 99 because they miss out on your perspective, experience and analysis. Further, every case class is a leadership laboratory for each student as they try to persuade their classmates (forget the instructor whom you’ll never see after this year). One watches what works and doesn’t work in terms of influencing your peers—and essential skill in the world. (For more see my book, Teaching Management published by Cambridge University Press.) Instructors who lecture to or embellish a book or assigned reading are adding virtually nothing to the learning of the students, learn very little about what the students are getting or not getting, ignore the education, work experience and personalities of the people in the room, teach students not to read the material since it’s “covered” in class, and miss out on assessing one of the most important student insights, how to influence in a group. Clearly, I am not a fan of lectures—I’ve sat through my share of them at Stanford, BYU, and Harvard. A skilled case instructor will pick cases that match the students and the topics at hand, pick technical notes and chapters that inform on current theoretical views, assume that students can and will read the material, insist that students come on time and prepared, ask carefully crafted questions that stimulate discussion, call on people who don’t volunteer, spread the opportunities to speak across the room, make appropriate notes and diagrams on chalkboards, flip charts, etc. for the visual learners, use and move seamlessly among various channels of communication like video clips, overheads, PowerPoints (sparingly), use poignant role plays as implied by student comments, manage time, manage energy, include humor, avoid any disruption to the flow of the discussion, encourage near end class reflection and insight making, and grade/assess the participation of all students after each class. Class participation comprised 50% of our grading systems. So, the very highest tier schools who develop learning systems that recognize what we know about adult learning will demand attendance, preparation, and participation—because the combination of all of that accelerates the learning of everyone in the room. We very successfully used case method in all ten disciplines—accounting, economics, decision analysis, finance, marketing, operations, ethics, leadership and organizational behavior, strategy and communications. In my experience over 40 years involved in worldwide academics, it’s the schools that rely primarily on lecture method, whatever tier one sees them in, that don’t care.

I am qualified to answer this, because I am a professor at an Ivy League university. No, I dont care. Indeed, students that can succeed without hand-holding are commendable. But the answer for the entire higher-education system is more complicated. However, I try to 'package' what I teach with my own lessons from life and consulting. To give something the books can not give. Moreover, I think (hope) the way I have put together my disciple(s) is unique - and will save my students years trying to do it for themselves…just like I wish my professors would have done with/for me. This being said, many lower ranked universities - those letting in less intellectually curious and more sheepskin seeking — need to require professors to care. Attendance represents a crucial signal when deciding if a student is keen but less able. In practice, most professors I know will grade students that try hard more easily. I personally think that results (comprehension and demonstrated ability to use the material) beats signs of trying hard (like attendance). But not all professors have the luxury of grading only on results/grades. I should also highlight the useful role that feedback from students plays in the way we teach (and sometimes even think)! If students do not attend, we can not know if our 'pitch' is good. Namely, are explanations clear and helpful? Are there alternative ways of thinking about a theory or precedent? Only direct feedback can help. As an aside, I should note that my students must attend 'class.' We teach here mainly by one-to-one tutorial. Reading their weekly essays is the only way we can assess students (though their degree results are often largely dictated by government administered exams run outside our sphere of influence). There are apocraphal stories of students never attending lectures and blowing off tutorials, and still getting a first-class or 2:1 degree. So to summarize, it should not matter. It does matter in many places. And it must matter when student participation detemines their grade/result. END

You’ve got so many answers to this question already, but thanks for the A2A all the same. These days, in-class attendance is supplemented by online classroom environments and recordings of lectures, so if one is hit by the proverbial bus and can’t attend, you can always engage your class and tutors online. It won’t be an adequate substitute for attendance and engagement for every kind of class, though. As for whether Professors might care if students don’t attend, I’ll leave you with a story I heard from the late 80s, from an Australian university where students had taken to setting up those old micro-cassette recorders to record the lectures they couldn’t stay for. As the weeks rolled by, in a particular lecture hall, at this particular Australian uni, the lecturer (the hero of our story), noticed that the numbers of orphan tape recorders on tables was growing. It got to the point where he was essentially lecturing a room full of cassette recorders set up to record his voice.  So, the following week, as students entered to set up their recording devices on each table, he pulled out his own cassette device, and pressing PLAY, departed the lecture hall. :)

I’m not a professor myself, but I’ve worked at staff positions at a couple of (U.S.) state universities with good national reputations, plus earned a couple of masters’ as well as my undergraduate degree. So I’ve been privy to to what a lot of professors said. (And left unsaid.) For the most part, the answer seems to be yes — assuming they care about the teaching aspect of their job. (You might, unfortunately, encounter some faculty members who only care about their research, or who are so burned out they don’t care about anything.) They prepare for their classes and stand up there giving their lectures for a reason, after all. This doesn’t necessarily mean they’re sticklers for attendance, however. In the case of large lecture classes — which I suspect you’re primarily asking about — trying to do that kind of record-keeping would be impractical. And the general attitude I encountered was that college students were considered adults, and if they missed classes they could deal with the consequences (if any) on their own.

Do professors in college care if you show up to class? Some do, some don’t. Some professors believe college students are young adults and have the right to choose. I kinda believe that to a point, but also know a bit about teaching and learning too. For a lot of good reasons, I did a fair number of group exercises in class, including how to form, lead, problem solve, and communicate in groups. Most people in organizations work in groups, so these are important skills. They are also highly valued by employers. If you think those are not important and worth going to class for, just browse around Quora, and check out all the bitter complaints about stupid bosses (can’t lead) horrid co-corkers (can’t communicate) nasty companies ( can’t plan or problem solve.) I also attached a participation grade to these group exercises. Although it was possible to earn a B, it was not possible to earn an A in my class without participating in the class exercises. Some people had to skip class for work or for family reasons. I understand that and worked with those students so they could earn an A. Reading the book and passing the exam is not thinking or learning, it is rote memorization. I could write a simple software program or maybe train a monkey to do that. Although I always treated my students with respect and kindness, I find it hard to respect the behavior of someone dumb enough to pay all that money and get into that kind of debt, and not get every scrap of learning possible out of a class and a professor. It’s also possible to take online degrees from some very fine schools for those who need more flexibility in scheduling courses. Some of these provide fully accredited degrees.

I certainly do, but, when teaching large 100+ classes, some professors won’t and realistically, can’t care about attendance. Attendance isn’t some kind of vote on how much you like the prof or the material. Attendance —when backed up by being prepared (having done the assigned readings, problems, homework, lab work—and when accompanied by baying careful attention, taking good notes, and, if possible, asking questions about anything you don’t understand does more than help you master the material. It helps the professor “read” the level of preparedness, background learning, etc. of the class in general and alter the lectures to fill knowledge gaps that are important if studenta are going to grasp the material. Most professors take great care in planning out their syllabi: presenting the right amount of material each day, making lectures relevant to students who have a variety of learning styles. Your questions and comments are how I judge, each day, what I need to do to “reach everyone.” In smaller classes (say, 40 or fewer students) discussion is vital to helping students go beyond learning material —learning the facts—you also need to develop skills: of reasoning, of writing, of explaining. You learn them by doing them with a coach-me-and with feedback from your peers—other students. So, yeah, I do care whether you attend, but if you’re sleeping or texting throughout class you are attending but not attentively. Your understanding, your test scores, your grade for the course will all suffer for that. Don’t cut corners by cutting class. You’re only cheating yourself.

I worked at a 2 year college and the subjects I taught were BORING to most students. They had to take Accounting 101 and Intro to Data Processing for any business degrees. Add to the yawn fact the total terror factor that many had on day one of AC 101 and you have a recipe for not wanting to show up. I took the classes with the non-DP/Accounting majors. I cared that you showed up in that I created material that I believed made these subjects a lot more interesting. If you wanted that business degree at RBI, you had to get past these two classes. You could take them from me, the one time entertainer, or my hard nosed colleagues. I was able to show almost everyone who put in their time that neither subject required that you be a math whiz, science genius, programmer or anything close to. All the same, I wasn’t going to chase you around campus, call you at home or send you mail if you didn’t attend. (No email back then.) I and my colleagues tried to relate what we taught to what you’d encounter on the job. Part of that is that many bosses don’t care, in the sense of “caring about you as a human,” if you don’t show up for work. They care about their budget, about having to hire again and that sort of thing. Much like when I was in a band, I cared that you liked what I played and that I put on a show that was worthy of your money. Along those lines, I always did my best to do my part. But hey, if you don't like Jazz-influenced blues or Accounting or just don’t like to get up in the morning … so be it.

Yes (and no). Yes, if you show interest and helps the class by asking questions that could help the entire class - there are many who do have questions, but seem afraid to ask - and a student who is not afraid to ask will actually help everyone. Yes, when you show a desire to learn that can be infectious actually - and will actually stimulate the instructor to do better and expand the boundaries (I know it did for me). No - if you are disruptive - if you come to class, open your laptop and start playing solitaire (I have actually seen this and asked the student to leave). No, if you answer your cell phone and talk when the class is in session. If you do not show up for class but then barge into the professor’s office asking questions, seek help - you better be prepared to be asked to leave. Those that do not bother coming to class should not expect to be helped outside of class - unless ofcourse there were good reasons for you to have missed class. If you do not show up for class, do poorly in the exams and expect to get a passing grade - forget it.

Yes, I do care very much that students come to class, but I don’t make them attend by requiring that they record their attendance somehow. They are fully grown adults. In my opinion, college students can and should have the choice to come or not to lectures. This is their education. Some students work better by themselves on the course material by themselves at home, and I respect that. Now I’m trying to make the class as interesting and as useful for them as possible, so that they actually do want to come to lectures and tutorials. This is good for me because it forces me to keep my classes up to date, using feedback from students whenever I can. I think classes should work as an exchange, not a one-way knowledge transfer. Note that in Germany and other northern European countries, non-tenured professors used to be paid directly by the students in return for their lecturing. I’m sure these lectures must have been very good ! For those students who do not like my droning or class style, I make my class material fully accessible online and try foster online after-class exchanges. This does not always work very well by the way. Many students seem only interested in their grades.

Most college professors don’t take attendance. You show up to class at your own time, which you should really do as this is your education and money that you paid to be there. This isn’t high school anymore, you are responsible for your own time management and asking your professor on following up on anything you missed if you had to be absent for one class. Most professors usually post their PowerPoint presentations, announcements for upcoming assignments or exams, and your grades on your Blackboard. You can also send emails to your classmates through Blackboard too, handy for doing group projects. You can pick class at a time that suits you. Morning person, you can pick 8:00 am classes. Night owl, you pick afternoon or evening classes. You get that level of flexibility in college/university. That is what makes college so much better compared to how monotonous high school was. More freedom and individuality along with having more like-minded people is why people prefer college/university over high school.

I teach writing, and have for 44 years. Most of the other professors here teach a lecture or lecture/lab course. Our situations are dramatically different. When students do not show up for class, then the problems show up on their papers. I usually do a combination of editing on their papers and a critique that i do orally, using software. It takes about 15 minutes to an hour per paper. If students do not show up for class and then turn in a paper, I find that I am constantly having to go over things on the paper that we covered in class. It slows my time way, way down, it takes away from students who were in class, and it almost always results in a much lower grade. I have heard almost every excuse in the book why students do not show up. One even said, “Well, I was playing basketball.” Fine . . . if you are on scholarship or playing in the NBA. But he wasn’t.

If the class is a large lecture class, it’s pretty tough for a professor to keep tabs on attendance. So in that case, it’s probably all on your shoulders to show up or not. But when the class is small enough for the professor to learn each student’s name, then the professor will definitely care if you show up for class. A big piece of the puzzle here is how the professor decides to teach the class and how that professor decides to grade student performance. If the whole thing is lecture with long exams on the material covered, then as long as you can access the material that was covered in the lecture and you can reproduce it on an exam you could likely pass the class without ever showing up. But if the professor likes to hold discussions and grades students based on their interactions with the course material during those discussions . . . you better be there in the front row.

College courses state whether attendance is required. If it is and you don’t go, it is the professor’s job to dock your grade. Whether attendance is required or not, if you don’t go and the class is small enough so that the professor notices, you are sending a message that their teaching isn’t worth your time. No one likes that message; do not expect a bouquet of roses and a warm letter of recommendation from that professor. If there is a reason for your absence, such as illness, tell the professor about it. If there is some reason why you can’t learn well in that class, also tell the professor. If you are not interested in the subject, drop the class. I don’t see much point in spending four years of your life and a ton of money for college, not going to class. I acknowledge that sometimes a student and a professor don’t mesh, and the student decides to learn the subject from books or from someone else. That may work out, but it should be a rare situation. Generally even if you don’t like the professor you will learn more by going to class than not going.

At Point Park University, the campus was tiny compared to Pitt. We were often the butt of many jokes due to our small class sizes and near-obsolete equipment. However, I’ll never forget just how much the professors at the NSET department cared about the students’ tracks. Burnout was a common ailment among my colleagues back then. About once a month, some of my professors would email me discussing attendance. I had great attendance records during the first two years, but when Junior year rolled around, my attendance slipped. My professors immediately noticed and brought it to my attention. A lot of my professors taught me for multiple semesters. My advisor was also my professor for Developmental Biology, Immunology, and Cellular Biology, so she took extra care for me and her students. She was stellar and made the best with what she had available. When my grades took a nosedive, she was legitimately upset. She was very passionate to see each and every one of her students succeed, and it touched me to this day. Ultimately, I did in fact drop out, but it was of my own volition. It was required for professors to take attendance at the university since our classes only had 30–40 or so people. I think it encouraged the students to go beyond and have great attendance records, but you were allotted 10 missed classes per semester before your grade was irreparably affected. Still, I believe this system was effective for our needs. I’ve sat in a few seminars at Pitt and CMU, and some of them had entire theaters of people. No way in hell to keep track of all those students! It’s a common trope to paint universities simply as a money-grab scheme and full of propaganda, but sweeping generalizations like these are blatant injustice. There’s a lot of good people in higher education who want nothing but the best for you — you’ll know it when you see it. These kinds of professors inspire students to strive for greatness. Of course, don’t expect your hand to be held. There’s only so much the staff can offer you. You still have to do the work in order to succeed!

Had a class in first year computing. The lecture theatre was largest normally used and seated about 1200 from memory. You had to get there early in the first week as all the seats filled and they closed the doors when it got very crowded. Well over 2000 enrolled in the course and only one class time was available! Thus extreme overcrowding. If late you could not get in. After a week, it was obvious from his lecturing in programming, he did not know what he was talking about. They hired him as a full professor as he designed many a mainframe. The trouble was, he did not know how to program in the languages he was supposed to to each.(I am not even sure he knew how to program at all!) He wrote simple programs on the board and explained how they worked. The trouble was, when we tried them, they never ever worked! It was so bad one student in our year, who did know how to program, denied him access to the mainframe. Any person who tried to log him in also lost access. The upshot, over half the academic staff lost access to the mainframe. They had to shut down the mainframe. Wipe the memory and reconfigure the hard drive. Not one of the lecturers knew how to overcome a simple program. We had three test and you needed to get over 60 in each test to pass. One student got just over 50 in the first test. Another student scrapped a 51 in the third test. Nobody got over 40 in the second test. He was that bad. After 2 weeks we went from standing home only with locked doors to seats available. By the half year mark we dropped below 40% attendance and by late in the second semester there were less than a dozen students. It was reported that some lectures in the final month had no attendance! No roll was taken as it was unthought of that this could happen in a large subject! As every person failed first year, the following year, only those who failed second year were in the second year course. Enrollment in the first year course dropped below 1000. The problem was it was near impossible to get anybody with the skills to teach programming to work for the pay the universities were paying in Australia. My wife’s cousin was first in his year in computing at Cambridge. His starting salary was 300 000 pounds a year or roughly $600 000 plus stock options in the finance sector. A full professor was paid about $120 000 a year in Australia the year he graduated in England. I hate to think what the top MIT and Harvard students would get! This is a reason why many subjects don’t take rolls. It can lead to embarrassing situations like this!

Having done that gig: ‘it depends’. While many instructors are passionate about their field(s), the industry is a business. What the business cares about is paying the bills and expanding the business. Some industries care if the bill payor is not present for the services rendered against the payment, but as long as’ the check clears’, most business are not concerned with how you exercise your purchase (like showing up for the class). That said, many Higher Ed instructors consider class participation a major component of the ‘educational process’ (varying by field/profession pursued/taught). Depending on the topics, not everything can be appropriately ‘absorbed’ remotely. When I took my Tech Writing Cert’, they didn’t just cover our writing, but editing your classmates work as well. And while some social interactions can be achieved ‘virtually’, not all learning nor instruction is best accomplished that way. Legal Studies often require the interpersonal training as well as the jurisprudence, same for much of the medical field. But going to a class to meet a requirement for something you can ace remotely? THAT is a waste of everyone’s time.

Lots do, lots don’t, and lots are ambivalent about it. Sort of a Venn Diagram of care. The same can be said about student sincerity on attending class. From my experience, attendance and final grade are correlative, not causative. In other words, attendance is not necessarily tied to success or failure in learning. In my mind, counting attendance is more of a CYA proposition than a valid factor in teaching success. I say this because in higher education there is so little effort put into making professors learn how to be better teachers. Many professors simply waste the student’s time, yet there they are taking attendance each class. In many ways, it is the focusing on the grade based on non-knowledge material that disturbs me, and rewarding a student for good attendance is one such problem. Attendance is also a factor in the traditional roll of the inert student. Students come up through a system that makes learning an observational function rather than an active one. Yes, I'm sure every Jr high and high school teacher out there uses active learning methods and they all teach students the ubiquitous “critical thinking” skills. Yet, somehow a substantial number of these students can’t actually perform those skills when they show up to college. Instead, they have all learned that the grade, not the knowledge, is the important issue. They also learn how to scam the teacher out of “extra credit” and “attendance points,” which are used to boost a grade above that which actually measures knowledge and ability.

It depends. In general faculty like attendance. It shows students are engaged. Heavy attendance suggests there will be a livelier dsicussion.At many schools, attendance may be required. At my school for example, missing four weeks in a row means you will be dropped. this follows a policy we negotiated with our accreditor.In general, higher attendance correlates to higher grades.That said, Many students especially grad students may have conflicts with other key activities (e.g., conference travel). If that happens and the student makes up missing work, smart professors will be cool.The better the student, the more they can achieve on their own. If a student is getting their work done, the professor may not be worried about a student missing classes.Some students may have already made alternate arrangements. This is common for students on competitive teams with travel commitments. don’t be surprised if a student on a team has already sat down for hours and done their work with a tutor.TLDR: usually attendance improves performance and the class experience, but smart professors know when to make exceptions. Thanks for the A2A Christian Wells

It’s been a long time since I was in college, but back in the early 80s my professors didn’t even take role. The problem was that you just couldn’t pass the exams if you didn’t show up, and often the only two grades for the entire course were the midterm and the final. Talk about pressure. Some universities have attendance requirements—like you can only miss four classes and still get credit. Some professors have graduate assistants you take roll for them. In general, I don’t think professors care if you show up or not and if you pass or not, particularly in those huge lecture classes. Unlike your high school teachers, they’re not going to hunt you down and ask you what’s wrong and how they can help. You’re a big kid now.

Yes. We prepare our lectures with great care. When I taught, my lectures would give an overview based on my insights and experience that the students could find nowhere else. Also, I would get immediate feedback from the students in two ways: 1) I could see if they were paying attention to what I was saying, or if they were bored or restless, and 2) They could ask questions. You might not know this, but even in an auditorium that held 100 students, I could look out and see each person. I also scheduled lab exercises and homework each week, and assigned an individual project, in which each student had to develop a unique questionnaire on a topic that interested him or her. I mentored each student individually at several stages of their projects. I did have 3 TA’s to help out with the labs, and yes, the students were expected to show up to both the lectures and the labs each week. By the way, the individual projects meant they had to do that work themselves, and could not copy someone else’s answers, because each project was different. What if the class is a special seminar or small discussion section in a larger class? You have an even greater obligation to show up and participate. Such sections are designed to help you learn, from the TA and from your fellow students. So, I have a question for you. Why wouldn’t you show up for class? If you are not interested, perhaps college is not the right place for you right now. Why not take a job now to gain experience in a field you might wish to work in later, or volunteer in a developing country to see all that you have now, all that you take for granted, from a different perspective? You might even join a program in which you teach students yourself, to gain another view of what your professors are trying to impart to you.

Some do and some don’t. Virtually everyone has heard about those students who go to class the first day and then are not seen again until the final. Of course, in some reality but mostly in modern legends, these students all have perfect GPAs, all manage to earn their degrees without ever cracking a book nor ever attending a class. As I said, that is mostly in modern legend. But, as said in the first line of this answer, some profs would almost you prefer that you not show up. Others not only want you to show up but make class attendance a part of your grade with the caveat that if you miss X number of classes, you will fail. College professors are actual human beings that vary widely. Some need an audience to sit like eager pups and lap up the words that spill forth from their mouths as if they were spewing some divine elixir. They need the audience. Others are simply so passionate about their field and are simply busting to share all they know and find others equally enamored. They cannot stand the idea of someone not knowing all there is to know about whatever. Others are in it for the money, managed to get the degrees and then started teaching college because it seemed like an easy gig. they really don’t care unless the university has given value to your class attendance. Generally, your class syllabus will outline attendance requirements. Word to the wise: If your syllabus does not say, don’t ask. Show up as much as you can.

I've noticed a strong correlation between low attendance and low test scores and I warn my students about this. I try to ameliorate this by assigning a lot of (graded) homework but the correlation still persists. I only take attendance the first few weeks and only for the purpose of learning my students' names. If a student that misses classes performs poorly in a test I will have a conversation with him/her to see what the problems are and give advice. The students that show up in class and perform poorly don't need any promoting to seek advice: they show up in my office, worried or outraged and I can do something about this. I don't care about attendance as long as it does not affect my students' performance.

That depends on what you mean by “show up”. If all you mean is “physically attend lectures”, then no. Not at all. (Except to the extent than some universities and/or scholarships require attendance records.) But if you mean “actively engage with the class material”, then yes, very much so! Depending on the class, active engagement may require attendance, but even then, mere physical presence isn’t enough.

From what I gathered talking with professors, they both do and do not. If “I” didn’t show up for class, for example, the professor might care because I tried to get to know them. Not showing up to class could signal that there is some problem in my life that is preventing me from attending, and professors I was closer to might worry about that. But it’s kind of a self-fulfilling prophesy. If you aren’t showing up for class and your professor can’t pick you out of a crowd, they won’t care because they don’t know you. You are just another seat in their class. But I suspect that if you didn’t care enough about their class to show up, I think they would care even less. You have made a choice as an adult or near-adult. If you don’t care about showing up, why should they?

My class isn't that big only 60 students in one class and there is a high chance that professor will know name of most of students. But you are talking about the King of introvert, the ruler of middle benchers. I have an ability to stay invisible to everyone, even my classmates got to know about my name in second year. There was a teacher who taught us 3 consecutive semesters and by that time he knew about top 3, front and back benchers and the chamchas. But there was one person he ignored. The middle bencher who scored 4th rank in class. One day I forgot to mark my attendance and when I told him about it his reaction was  And it wasn't just him most of teacher didn't know about me. But eventually they got to know about me because I used to solve alot of questions and hide them and they checked & remembered my name. (Still regret it tho)  So to answer your question my professors know about me but they don't care if I show up or not as long as I maintain my 75% attendance. . . . Arigato…

Depends on the professor. Some take roll, some give participation points, and some don't do anything but if you don't show up and later try to say you need help at the end of the class, you might be in trouble. Some professors are very well aware of who is there and who isn't, especially if they don't have 100 or more students in their classes. But yes, there are those who don't care if you don't show up to class. But that means you better be aware of when assignments, tests, and exams are due. Late assignments usually won't fly.

I have taught about sixty college/university courses so far in my career, none with more than fifty students in them. I think if I had a huge lecture hall type class, i would certainly not care. I care in that I think it will help your understanding of the concepts and give you the best opportunity to learn, to ask questions, to stay connected. I do not care in that I think my lecture or class discussion is just one tool at your disposal (along with course readings, assignments, research papers, supplemental videos and class materials, databases, etc.). I have no ego invested in you being present. I care in the case of universities that require me to take attendance, because I have to submit attendance reports. I do not care because you are adults. You can make your own choices. And you can suffer the natural consequences - like the fact that students who do not show up to class regularly do more poorly on exams and in their writing than those who are present and engaged. I care because I know that if you are not in class, and you do not read the syllabus, and you do not check in on Blackboard or Brightspace or whatever we are using, you will suddenly face a crisis at the end of the semester and email me lengthy complaints about why your C+ (which really should have been a low D) ought to have been an A-. And nobody has time for that.

We’d actually prefer that you don’t, the fewer of you the better. Just don’t skip class then come in during office hours and ask for a summary. My favorite line from a student I met in the hallway, “I couldn’t come to class today, did you talk about anything important?”

“Care”? Well, if they are interested in your success, they likely care if you are not there. Do they worry/care like a high school teacher does? Not likely, since a high school teacher has a responsibility for your welfare and success if you are in his class… which often includes attendance. A college prof has no such responsibility, hence doesn’t chase absent students. The college already has your money and every student has the “right to fail”.

Yes, I cared if you showed up to class. Otherwise you were not going to pass, as work and discussion in class (individual and small groups) was 40% of the grade. There was also a notable correlation between attendance and performance on assessments and projects. My college teaching experience was limited to teaching teacher certification courses in psychology and classroom management. You also had to read the assigned educational research articles, as classroom discussions quickly established if you'd done the reading or not. Like many college-level instructors, I did not take attendance after the first few weeks, but did grade the daily work completed in class. It was pretty easy to pass my courses. All you had to do was show up, do the reading, participate in the classroom discussions, and say something reasonably cogent during the discussions. Yet, some people were not able to do those simple tasks.

I do. Most/all professors I know do. If we generalize the most engaged stakeholders in the students attending college universe: knowledge receivers/degree earners (students)knowledge deliverers/learning facilitators (professors)bill payers (usually parents)degree providers (colleges and universities)…the last 3 all want you to attend class. And, you the first, should want to attend class. It’s kind of how the process is meant to work. Some professors may have become jaded and cynical and don’t care much; but I suspect (hope!) those professors are in the distinct minority. Viewed differently, this question is like asking a store owner: do you care if anyone comes into your store and buys your products? The answer should obviously be a resounding yes! For either full-time faculty or adjunct/part-time faculty, they are loosely equivalent to the vendor—in this case peddling knowledge. Viewed this way, of course they want you to attend class. Even after years of teaching, I hope they have enough love of their topics and love of the process of informing inquisitive minds as to be motivated to teach. And any motivated teacher worth their salt wants motivated students to engage with. So, fair question, but after my verbose wandering, hopefully you can see that from your professors’ points of view, you should definitely go to class. I hope this helps.

Full disclaimer: I am not a college professor. However, as someone who has taken four years worth of college courses, I think I can give perhaps a teensy amount of insight. For the vast majority of my classes, attendance was mandatory. Professors ensured this through the use of iClickers, daily in-class assignments, pop quizzes, and so on. Of course, this may be something particular to my major, but from anecdotal feedback I have learned that it is this way in many other majors (and universities around my area) as well. One important thing to note is that not all of my classes were taught by professors. Some were taught by lecturers, and all of my labs were taught pretty much exclusively by teaching assistants. Variation existed between different instructors as well; not all professors (or lecturers or TAs) will care. For the most part, professors who did not make attendance obligatory still cared whether or not students showed up. They noticed, and some of them would call us out on it during and after class. By the end of the semester, the instructor often knew which faces (if not names) were usually present, if the class had 50 or fewer people in it (i.e. if it was not a class that took place in a lecture hall). So in my experience, most professors do care, even if attendance isn’t mandatory.

Whether the professor cares if you show up doesn't matter. You'll care if you don't show up when your grade reflects that you are behind on the work and lack understanding of the material. Bad habits start early, better to ask yourself why am I wasting my or my parent's money on college and not showing up to class. You will end up on academic probation by making cutting classes a habit. Look at it like this. Your education is your job, how long will your boss wait until he/she fires you for chronic absenteeism? See the correlation?

It really depends on your professor one of my professors said if you are 5 min late more than 3 times you get 1/3 marked off your if your more than 5 minutes late don’t bother coming to class you won’t be let in. Another of my professors said I completely understand you have other obligations and some of you are off campus so you may hit traffic ect just be respectful of other student when entering also if your are predicting to be routinely late if you communicate with your professors they will be much more understanding than you might think

It depends on the University you’re attending and perhaps the program you are in. If you were a student at Georgia Tech, the answer would be no. The professor wouldn’t care if you: Never showed up for classNever completed assignmentsNever took exams.You would earn an F for the course and fail. It’s that simple. At universities like Tech, students are weeded out. Some will tell you that you graduate from that university by attrition… Universities like this make it understood that it is the student’s responsibility to get themselves to class, to study without being told, to do that which is necessary without being led by the hand. Other universities are more compassionate. Where a school like Tech weeds students out, other universities try to retain students. And professors there often actually pay attention to attendance. Personally, I believe professors should never have to worry about: Taking attendanceAssigning homeworkGiving quizzesGiving reading assignments or worksheetsIf you want to learn the subject, then show up to class, listen to the lecture, take notes, and then go study. How long should you study? Until you understand the material. What do you study? Everything and anything you can that helps you learn the material. THAT should be the choice and responsibility of the student.

One of the things that determine whether an instructor cares is whether a professor notices. In a large class, the instructor can’t tell if you show up or not, but in a small class, it’s obvious. If the class has less than 15 students, please show up for every meeting that you can. These are the best classes and student participation makes them that way. Small classes can include a lot of interaction that make for a better education. There are a lot of other factors that determine whether the instructor cares, not the least being his or her personality, but class size is one major factor.

Some do, and some don’t. Many if not most professors want students to do well, and attendance is a benefit in most cases. Large lecture sections with published source material and notes isolate students from instructors. But participants in small classes at senior levels where you know your prof tend to be quite involving, and there is much to miss. Professors are working for a living; good attendance (and good reviews) supports gaining tenure. Writing and researching compete with classroom instruction for a tenured professor’s time; his attention to students’ attendance can flag. After all, a student is primarily responsible for what happens to him at college; you want to skip lectures? OK.

Yes. Very generally, success in a class is tied to attendance. I have a strict attendance policy, as mine are lab classes that have experiences one can’t “read” about, but extend reading into pedagogical knowledge and action. I really don’t understand why anyone would pay to attend a class and then just not go. If the class is irrelevant, you can drop it. You can even drop without losing money by doing it within a certain period of time (albeit short) or you can drop later without grade consequence. Most of the people I teach with do care if students are in class or not, and reach out when that doesn’t happen.

Majority of college professors do not care if you show up or don’t show up to class. However, those who teach passionately and wants you to succeed, care if you show up and ask questions in their classroom. Don’t forget, most of them are there to teach and get paid a high salary—so whether you decide to show up or not, it isn’t really their problem. As a college student, I know some teachers care if you show up to class to succeed. I know some, who do not care if you don't show up to class. Either way, most college professors DO NOT CARE if you show up or not. They have a billion assignments to grade and will not remember who you are. They have their own families to care and worry about. Cheers.

Do professors in college care if you show up to class? I do care. I taught mostly pre- and postdoctoral students. Classes are small, usually 3 to 5 students, and 10 at most. Hence, when a student did not show up, there is a glaring absence in the class. My method of teaching is to have the students read the required material and showcase their knowledge by lecturing and sharing with fellow students their understanding of the material. My job as a professor is to extend and help integrate the material from books, research papers, and students’ input and ideas. I do understand it is different from undergraduates where intro classes could have several hundred students, and the professors could only know handfuls of students. Hence, attendance may be up to the student or the TA who is in charge of attendance. When I was an undergraduate in an ethics class, I had a professor who at the very first class noted students are pre-occupied with grades. He announced that everyone would get an A in the class, and the students just need to pay attention to understanding the material and not the grade. In the next class, almost nobody showed up. This professor learned his lesson and reversed his decision of giving everyone an A.

Yes. This is a question at the nexus of two important, but opposite concepts for what is good for students. On the one hand, I don’t care. A big part of going to college is taking responsibility and learning to do your best job to complete assignments. That’s what employers want. So I shouldn’t have to take attendance. Students should act as adults. Students should come to class to do their best job of learning. But they don’t… So on the other hand, many studies show that students who don’t come to class don’t learn nearly as much and do poorly with their grades. So I must take attendance and count it as part of the grade. The difference is often that between having 75–80% attendance (with a penalty for not attending) to 25–30% attendance. I can’t in good conscience let my students damage their prospects by demonstrating that they are not adult enough to be responsible. So I must treat them like children.

It depends. As a full-time student at a private university, most of my professors have attendance policies; if you miss 2+ classes, your grade drops. Most of my classes are small 8–15 students) so the professors know who is missing. On the other hand, I don’t take attendance in my class after the first month or so (by then I learn the names) but I do know who’s in class and who isn’t. I teach human anatomy & physiology, which I’ve taught for 12 years now. I know from experience that those who skip class and only appear for exams will not pass the class; I share this tidbit with them the first day of class. My classes are also fairly small 16–24 students so I know who attends and who doesn’t.

When I was in college, we were told by our professors that their paychecks did not depend on our attendance or ability to pass the classes. Your tuition was paid for already so the school has your money. So it’s totally up to you to do the right thing or not. I understood why the professors said that. It’s college and not high school. There were no letters home or parent conferences. You were an adult and it was up to you to pass or fail, attend or not. My daughter teaches in college. Part of her job is to log in class attendance. Many 101 classes require that you attend 80% of the time. These classes give you an automatic passing grade if you attend each but did no work. If you did work you get a better grade. My daughter asked about the attendance requirements and she was told that many students receive scholarships or tuition assistance money. Many require that the student attend class. In today’s computer age, it’s easy to log in who attends and who doesn’t. It is understandable that if your tuition has been covered, the agency that pays it would like to know you didn’t waste it.

When I taught I allowed students with decent grades (B+ or better) to have an interview with me at the end of the course where we can go over their work, and we can perhaps push their grade up a step. If I didn’t recognize them, or I knew they didn’t show up to lectures the interview didn’t go so well. The students that I recognized from class had a better experience. I could tell if students were genuinely trying, or if they weren’t respecting the course. They are adults, and it is their life. I am happy to help when they are willing to take it.

A2A - I think I answered this question with “yes”, “no”, and “maybe” at some point in my relatively short teaching career (6 years full-time, around 11 years with TAships/adjuncts). If you are not sure, read the syllabus. Listen to your professors. If the answer is “yes”, you will be made aware. In my current position (a regional public university), I care and require my students to send me an e-mail if they are going to be absent. I care as most important part of the learning process is the class interactions. If you miss a class, that will affect other students. When I was teaching at a SLAC, I was even more strict as my classes were small and even missing two students meant I had to change my lecture plan. Moreover, our advising was very hands-on, so I even cared if one of my advisees missed any class even if it was taught by another professor. At another institution, I was teaching a service course (i.e. +150 students) and really did not care who was there or wasn’t. I mean, I wasn’t even sure how many students I had. That being said, as one of the answers mentioned below, if you are going to show up and just be on your laptop the entire time, don’t show up.

I have generally tracked attendance. Students can, at a theoretical level, “succeed without hand-holding”. However, I’ve been teaching CS for many years now, and I’ve never seen the student who did master the material without attending class. I use low-stakes assessments (e.g., frequent quizzes and homework) to reinforce the concepts and skills I teach, and those grades, along with attendance, make up the barometer I use to decide when to intercede with students before they screw up completely by failing a major exam, etc. Students need to learn to be accountable to themselves, and I worry that I’m undermining their ability to do this. However, they’ve had their hands held so much before they arrive in my classroom that I think that a few comments or emails that I sent will provide the appropriate mix of increased independence and the ability to stay back from the cliff. However, I’m not at a research university. That will change expectations. I also teach relatively small classes (about 35 students each).

I’m not sure if you’re joking or serious. Of course they care. For most professors the interaction with students is one of the most important things in their lives. They understand that some absences are to be expected; that’s why there are usually a number of allowed absences. But ordinarily a lot of what you learn does depend on how the material is presented. And one of the most important things you may learn is what that particular professor thinks about the material. Because most subjects are not simple and clearcut. There is usually a subjective element. If the professor is interested, ideally passionate, about the subject, you are coming into contact with a point of view. That’s what makes a subject come alive.

Today, I have no idea. Back in the Jurassic Era, when I was teaching college English, a certain percentage of absences earned an F. Why? First, to me, it showed zero commitment to learning. But, more importantly, we had a lot of classroom discussion, and class participation was a significant portion of the grading total. There’s no point in enrolling in a class if you don’t have the time or inclination to master the material. And at today’s tuition prices, it doesn’t make any sense. Note: I’m talking about old-fashioned, “live” classroom experience these days. As time goes by, electronic and interactive media will likely redefine that experience as well as how it’s measured.

Depends on the professor. If attendance forms any part of their grade calculation, they care. Consider what happens in the classroom: Explanation of course assignments, feedback on assignments, sharing course content, Questions and answers, debate and discussion, socialization to academic norms, the real time development of critical thinking, the creation of a learning community and a professional social network. I wonder why students sign up and then rarely make an appearance. Those students never perform well and rarely manage a passing grade. Whether the professor cares or not is less important than whether the student cares.

Not very much. Unless so few students show up the first day, that the minimum number of students, as defined by administration, don’t show up. Then the class may be cancelled, at least for the current term. Remember that even though an instructor may be called “professor”. They may only be an adjunct professor without tenure. Too many empty classes may cause their being dropped as instructors, Tenured professors don’t get axed under the same circumstances.

I have generally tracked attendance. Students can, at a theoretical level, “succeed without hand-holding”. However, I’ve been teaching CS for many years now, and I’ve never seen the student who did master the material without attending class. I use low-stakes assessments (e.g., frequent quizzes and homework) to reinforce the concepts and skills I teach, and those grades, along with attendance, make up the barometer I use to decide when to intercede with students before they screw up completely by failing a major exam, etc. Students need to learn to be accountable to themselves, and I worry that I’m undermining their ability to do this. However, they’ve had their hands held so much before they arrive in my classroom that I think that a few comments or emails that I sent will provide the appropriate mix of increased independence and the ability to stay back from the cliff. but I’m not at a study institution. That'll change objectives. I also teach reasonably little classes (about 35 pupils each).

Hi Christian - I cannot speak for professors but as a lecturer, I definitely cared. The reason for this is quite obvious. I cared for the wellbeing of my students. I also prepared my lessons so that students would enjoy participating in lectures. My method of teaching involved asking questions at critical moments to provoke thinking. My knowledge is that students are more likely to fail if they do not attend lectures. I also felt that if the students are not attending my lectures than my lectures must be boring and uninteresting. For these reasons, I cared if the students showed up and participated in my lectures. For me, it was not just a question of showing up, it was also a question of active participation or sitting at the back of the class, on the last row, nearest the door.

It depends. At a small liberal arts college, maybe. The classes are small, and the professors probably know the students by name. At a large university, probably not. I work at a small liberal arts college, and I’m somewhere in between. It’s annoying if a student who doesn’t bother to show up to class asks questions that I’ve already answered, and if a lot of students were to stop showing up, I might wonder if I’m doing something wrong. In a class with a lot of discussion, I do require attendance. But at the end of the day, college students are adults who can make their own decisions, and I get paid either way.

Mostly no. It's up to you to show up to class to hear the lecture. Without that, it'll be difficult to pass. They treat you as an adult, meaning it is 100% your responsibility, but they do notice too. If you're in the situation of beinging boarderline on a grade, most will give you the benefit of the doubt and bump it up if you've been going. Conversely, if you haven't been going to class, they are inclined not to give the better grade.

I cared that my students took their college education seriously and made good use of the opportunity that they were offered. If not, I would prefer that they make space for someone who would. For my particular classes, I wanted students to be engaged - because that made the class better for everyone. Classes should not be a place where, as a student, you just receive information. You have textbooks and the internet for that. Classes should be places where you engage with the material as well as with your professors and the other students, raise good questions that others may not have thought about - and therefore contribute to your own education as well as that of the rest of the class. Did I care if every student was in attendance at every class? No. And I never took attendance. But I noticed whether every student was engaged or not. Sitting in a classroom is not important, but participating in what is going on is. College is expensive in lots of ways - time, money, effort. Make good use of the opportunity.

Some may, some may not. I had a high school teacher who taught English. He stated the assignment, then said if you need help I'm right here, if you need to leave, I'll write you a pass, gone more than 15 minutes, you've lost your points for the day. He was teaching the students heading off to college that your professor won't be holding your hand, you are a adult and have to be somewhat responsibility for our actions, we are no longer in high school, we are adults.

Whether or not a professor cares if you show up for class depends on the size of the class and how it is graded. If attendance figures into a student’s mark, then a teacher will feel obligated to keep track of individual attendance trends that stand out and may require a warning. In a few American colleges, a small number of cuts may result in a student's being failed in a course; this is the way it was during my first two years at college. Draconian. That system in now quite rare—probably to the relief of almost all professors; they have better things to do than waste time calling roll every meeting. Even today, however, if a student fails to attend a very small seminar, say Ancient Greek, the professor will definitely care, as that absence could reduce the quality of the class for the other students. Few colleges can afford to offer undergraduate classes for 3–10 students, but, if you are taking such a course, you’d best show up or have a good excuse. The professor will notice your absence and will not appreciate it. Treat your teachers with respect for their needs.

Yes, they care. They’re teachers. They won’t, however, do anything like lower your grade for it. College students are adults. They need to act like adults. Care about learning and go to class, or get the information some other way. Or drop the course, because not learning anything will show up as failing tests and college professors are not going to babysit you through that. If it’s a rule, it’s in the syllabus. Read it. Follow it. Be an adult.

This is a very interesting question and shows the difference between “brick and mortar” and “online” institutions. At the “brick and mortar” institution where I taught doctoral students advanced statistics, it was prohibited by the faculty senate to use attendance in class as a component of a grade. However, at “online” institutions, participation is key to obtaining the ability to grant federal financial aid. Therefore, participation at “online” institutions is very important to student success and financial viability.

Some do and some don’t. I can remember a professor telling the class that we only needed to be there for the midterm and the final exam. Being fresh out of high school this sounded pretty exciting. It didn’t take long for me to figure out that the class required a lot of note taking and the tests were taking almost exclusively from the prof’s notes.

Most profs are human beings and care about the welfare of their students, but a big part of college is for students to be treated and encouraged to be the adults they are. You are your “boss.” In my classes, and I am sure in most others, a student being regularly present correlated strongly with his or her success. A few students were so well equipped for college work that they could do very well on their own; a few were so ill equipped for college work that being in class regularly made no difference. I did refuse to run surveillance for police, divorce lawyers, parents, employers, statisticians, what have you. The college is the weight room. You do the lifting. Chris Schneider

Usually they don’t because it is your educational experience and at this stage you should be mature enough to figure out what you want out of it. However, there may be exceptions to this rule of thumb, and you would do well to make careful note of them especially if the particular class is a “mandatory attendance” one or if the Prof is a note taker and makes a mark on your record if you miss class. Nobody is going to come around and yell at you “get your ass outta bed it is time for xxxx class”. You need to grow up and get the education you are paying dearly for.

Well, I did not go to a normal school. I was held accountable if I missed a class at my school. But during my stint at a civilian college, the Professors did not care if I attended a class or not. I think I once had a civilian college class where the Professor noted attendance, with the thought that if you at least attended the lectures he bothered to put together you would pass the course. Good Luck and God Bless - MS

Depends on the professor, the school, and the department. 90% of my classes had required attendance. I dont know what the official attendance requirement was because I followed what the professor stated in their syllabus. One class I only showed up for the tests and the last two days. I was fortunate because those last two days, she gave out bonus points which put me into the A range of points, while my friend who had been as absent as I was, didnt go to the final classes and ended up with an 89.4. She had no attendance requirements. Many of my classes had less than 50 students, and in my final semester was the only time more than once of my classes had more than 40. It was a shock to all of my professors as well.

Yes, I care a lot. I teach undergraduate teaching students (BA in Primary Education) and my teaching is seminar workshop based. Students will miss workshops in practical teaching activities (phonics for reading and spelling, drama, art, learning outside the classroom, science, for example) as well as important lectures on child protection, pedagogy and working with parents. In fact I’m reluctant to send students on their school placements if they have missed too many lectures and I set them vivas to demonstrate that they have enough knowledge and understanding.

In my country public colleges doesn't really care since education is given free to them mostly via scholarships. I studied in a private college where professors actually check on us in every single class that we need to attend. Even lateness are taken into account. My advice, if you pay to get an education, attend the classes before the professors care.

Yes absolutely. They take take role everyday. Some professors have a policy that after three absences they can drop you. I’ve never seen that done. But one needs to go to class to be successful. It’s a matter of showing your professor and peers that you mean business. Respect. The bottom line is that if one is on the border of a c or a B. I firmly believe the student who comes everyday will get that B instead of the C . Showing up on time is important too since it is disruptive to walk In A class late

I care because the ones that show up on a regular basis, are the ones that pass (there are always exceptions). There are of course lots of good reasons why students don’t turn up, jobs, caring responsibilities, sickness and disability, so I try not to judge or feel demoralised.

If they care about their students, they should. A person may be able to learn, to a degree, by getting someone’s notes or listening to a recording of the class, but they lose the ability to ask questions which can help clarify something they may be unsure about. Many professors (too many, probably) are in it for the prestige and the academia. They are there to write and publish and have to “deal with” the drudgery of actually teaching classes. I am sure these professors could care less if you show up or not.

In general, there is a steady decline in involvement of “professors in college” with classes. I think that few professors take and record (I don’t remember any) attendance as a component of the course grade. I think that most, who are actually teaching, believe that attendance enhances the learning experience and care that their students have a good learning experience (including, but not limited to, showing up to class).

It depends on the professor. Having taken dozens of college courses I can tell you almost every professor I have been taught by always cared about attendance. It will also be stated in the syllabus that attendance is mandatory and will be included in the participation grade for the class. I would say in all honesty the most number of classes I ever missed over the course of a semester was 6 classes. In this particular class, it was a class that all freshman had to take. It honestly did not make much of a difference to me. I passed this class. So in the end I think it should be your discretion when missing classes.

I went to a small university in Switzerland, so courses were really smaller than most imagine. At the beginning of the second year, I was late by three or four weeks because I was in the army - a perfectly normal situation. I went to greet one of the English literature professors at the end of the first course I attended after coming back - to my surprise, he greeted me by my surname and asked if I had been to war, with a grin… so some do, at least, and will know if you don’t show up. They then may or not take retaliatory measures when marking your exams or during an oral examination!

You personally in particular? Probably not. You in general? Probably. That is to say: I, and many of my colleagues, do not closely track who is there any given day, particularly for large undergrad classes. But we notice if half the class is gone, and we get concerned about how lack of attendance affects success.

Not much but when you have a problem they can get terse and remind you its not right you missed the class and now you want tutoring. The classes are often the best clues as what will be on tests. You need to read the nook for the test. Test question are things that read like a question, are important to the chapter principles and meaningful to the course. If you outline the book and pay attention to ”this will be on the test” you will then memorize and study your outline.

I’m pretty sure they do. I mean you pay to be in their class and listen to them and it’s kinda rude if you don't show up to class. Even the big lecture halls, you should still try to show up. You’re paying for their time, the least you can do is show up and try to show some interest in their topic.

Some of them will include attendance as part of your grade. However, this isn't high school anymore. You are paying for the class so it's up to you to be responsible and go to class. If you are smart enough to take the exams and do well in the class then you probably never have to show up other than for exams.

nope. you’re an adult and need to take care of your own affairs. i think most colleges and universities might have a program to provide some sort of intervention for students who are not doing well. as far as professors go, the saying, “i don’t think we are in kansas anymore” holds true. unlike high school teachers, professors are not going to care.

It would depend upon class size. If they do not ‘know’ you, then there is little they can do about it after all, as long as you show up to the midterms and final. Don’t forget that some courses are taken ‘pass/not pass,’ such that simply reading the assignments can land a passing grade without much classroom attendance.

The one thing you can do to draw unwanted attention to yourself as a student is to have poor class attendance. It is unfortunately not too unusual for students to stop coming to class after a week or so, to give up doing the homework after a month or so, to not show up for exams, AND TO NOT DROP THE CLASS. This conveys a clear message to the professor, and to your advisor… and it’s a message that you have no place in a university environment.

That depends. In a giant lecture hall with 400 students, they neither know nor care if you show up. at some universities, these lectures are broadcast online so they can register more students than they have seats in the lecture hall. But in the small classes that are discussion-based, if you don’t show up, you can’t participate and you won’t pass.

I taught for 36 years. I don’t ever remember being in a class that took attendance, and I rarely did myself. In a few smaller classes I did, to learn peoples’ names. But we do know who attends regularly, by sight if not by name. And there are classes that are heavily based on discussions, and those classes often do have required attendance, which is part of the grade. My feeling is they can vote, buy cars, have babies, and are adult enough to decide whether to attend class.

On the whole, probably not, if it's a lecture. If on the other hand it's tutorial or a lab class, enquiries and investigations are likely to be made if there is more than a single absence. The reason for the distinction is that that tutorials and lab classes require student participation, to learn essential skills. Lectures in contrast may be covered by reading books.

I went to small universities for both my undergraduate and postgraduate degrees. I can tell you that at the universities that I went to, attendance was compulsory. But then, with an average class size of 30, it was easy to monitor attendance. If you study at a large university where there are many lectures that are attended by hundreds of students, the lecturers may not care about attendance at all. As a university professor myself, I can tell you that I DO care about attendance in my classes. In China, in addition to exam grades, university students also get marks for things like attendance, punctuality, behavior, doing homework, enthusiasm etc.

When I taught I allowed students with decent grades (B+ or better) to have an interview with me at the end of the course where we can go over their work, and we can perhaps push their grade up a step. If I didn’t recognize them, or I knew they didn’t show up to lectures the interview didn’t go so well. The students that I recognized from class had a better experience. i really could tell if pupils had been truly attempting, or if they weren’t respecting the program. These are typically grownups, and it is their life. Im thrilled to help if they are happy to go on it.

Some don’t care, and some care so much that they take roll every day. Some professors take absences into account when assigning grades (class participation). I always wondered when a student missed a lot of classes but didn’t hold it against the student. I assigned grades solely on student performance. Sometimes, I asked about the absences but don’t think I got an honest answer very often.

I go to a very small university where many of the profs take attendance and as much as 15% of our mark is for participation. If you miss more than three classes the profs have the right to drop you a full letter grade and in extreme circumstances, ban you from the final exam resulting in a F. My school cares, but it might be the exception and not the norm.

Technically, no. However, you will always have a few who go above and beyond and do care. But for the most part you are paying to be there. And depending on what stage you are at in your education it could matter. When I was doing my student teaching we were only allowed to miss 3 days that semester. Otherwise, we started over.

It depends on the college. Yes, professors care, but sometimes they don’t care enough to treat you differently. Some colleges require attendance as a part of the grade. Others don’t. It will be explained the first day of class. It seems like they will assume you have something to do if you have a habit of not showing up to class but still do well in your classes. For me it was wrk and sometimes I couldn’t schedule work around my classes. Sometimes the professor I was working for had to have me work at one time even if it was during a class.

As I am well trained in statistics (and taught biostatistics, along with zoology, ecology, environmental science, comparative animal physiology…) I did a lot of my own analyses of my classes. One thing I found (to my gratification) that when I team-taught ecology, the other professor and I had virtually the same grade distribution (no significant differences in mean, median, standard deviation, or skewness/kurtosis). Another thing I learned was that each class that a student missed resulted in an approximately 10% lower grade on the next exam. Moreover, students who missed five or more classes nearly always failed the class. I shared these results with my students on the first day of class and, for those absent on the first day, in the syllabus. I was required to take attendance, so I gave a short quiz at a random point during the class on each day that there was not an exam. That helped with improving attendance.

Not as much as some students think. In seminars attendance is mandatory and participation is a part of the grade. In lectures exams cover material from lectures not in the reading. I always told students that hearing me talk was a large part of what their parents were paying for in their tuition checks. I didn’t promise to be entertaining but only to be informative. Class attendance was correlated with grades. I was not bothered when students didn’t show up. Not insulted.
I’ve been a professor in colleges and in seminary in the United States and overseas as well. As teachers, we teach students, not books and outlines. Of course we care if students show up for class.

University of Manchester, UK is very strict about attendance and handing in coursework on time. Minus 25% penalty mark for coursework handed in up to 2 weeks late. In contrast at Imperial College London they accepted course work that was 7 months late, even after we had sat the summer examinations. No penalty marks.This was for a Master's course in the 1990s. Presumably because they know only the very brightest students are not going to fall behind. If the missing coursework is the difference between passing and failing that exam they will encourage you to get it done.

When I taught a college class I did. This often depends on the university or college. Smaller universities/colleges tend to take attendance much more seriously. If you do not go to class, participate, listen to lecture, what do you get out of the class?
