Nope, I surely don't. That's just me though. Failure to attend will almost always manifest itself. So there is no need to waste time taking attendance aside from the first week or so of class (everybody shows up the first couple weeks because disbursement of financial aid is dependent upon this).

I don’t take attendance and I don’t really care if students come to class. I tried to take attendance a few times (it is considered a best practice at our university) but it ended up being too much work. Students miss class for lots of legitimate and not so legit reasons. It was a pain to manage. I now record my lectures and post the links so that students can listen to them if they miss class (so, no excuses for not having the info). That said, I do like it when students come to class because they ask good questions and have things to contribute. It would suck to give a lecture to an empty classroom.

Freshman lectures with hundreds of students, not directly, but what's the point of taking the class? I did have a great class at Cornell that always ran over, and was so far from the next class that you couldn't get there time. Neither class tracked attendance, so a bunch of us skipped the second class and worked on its' assignments. Professor never knew or cared.

A2A: that depends on the professor. I personally make attendance a mandatory component in my classes, and assign to it 10% of the whole grade; it’s a differentiator between letter grades; A and B; and B and C. That’s to say I do care about students showing up to classes and office hours.

Some do. In my experience at a large, public university, most STEM courses expect/hope students don’t show up to class regularly (since there are a ridiculous amount of students enrolled) while in many humanities courses, attendance is mandatory and graded.

Given that students can choose to show up or not, declining classroom attendance signals a of lack of perceived relevance. Some students will show up out of habit or duty, but if the room is nearly empty by the end of the semester, you are lost as an instructor. The challenge is to keep students interested in what you have to say — combining surprise with topical humor and reminders of why what you are teaching is important for their futures.

If you are planning on passing the class,you need to show up. Is your professor going to bird dog to get you there? Most likely not. As a college student you are an adult and you make your own choices. Choices have outcomes good or bad and you deal with them.

Some of the professors here are holding out on you. If you take a course from me, I expect you to be in class on time every day. I take attendance every day. If you don’t show up, you’re probably going to fail. I don’t have to make attendance a factor; absence is it own penalty. And by the way, I have to report last date of attendance when I report a final grade of F. That can put a crimp in your financial aid.

Yes,but unlike high school, they will not pursue you, nor plead with you to attend. This lack of responsibility on the part of freshmen students is one of the main reasons so many fail and drop out in their first year. They received so much babysitting in earlier years that they can’t get by without it, and thus fail in college and life.

You Damned well they do!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! If you are so darned smart then you need to FIND a job!!! As an EMPLOYER IF you ever get to be one?????? How are you gonna feel IF your workers don’t show up regularly forcing you to have to use others in order to get production out the door and ON TIME! That question sent shivers down my spine.

Yes, in fact to encourage good class attendance my total course grade has attendance at 5%. I teach a many health, pre-medical, pre-pharm, pre-radtech students. Let me just say I want my students to develop good habits for their professional school and their work obligations. It starts with class attendance. If the student is late, then no attendance points are given. I really do not want students who do not attend class and arrive on time.

Speaking only for myself . . . not so much. I mean, I think it’s better for a student to be there than not. There is a great deal to be picked up by being present and an active (or even passive) participant in the ongoing discussions. However, it’s the student’s money that’s being wasted by not attending. If a student could learn on his/her own and do well on the various assessments that occur throughout the semester, more power to him/her!

It’s not good for professors if students don’t go to class, but it’s worse for the student. Not only do they lose the chance of hearing wisdom, they miss the chance to interact with classmates, have their ideas tested, and establish their own credibility. Another reason can be found if you divide the tuition and other fees by the number of classes you have during the year. You are throwing someone’s money away with both hands. Also, you are taking up the space of someone who may really want to be there. One or two cuts during four years is okay; not more,

Simple answer is that why should the professors care if you show up for class or not? You are supposed to be an adult, responsible and capable, I think? Anyway, you paid for the course and the university/college has your money so what do they care? Let you know you are absent from class? Be real!!!

Yes. Especially those professors who concentrate their careers in the classroom. They want to teach, they want to pass on the knowledge they have, it’s their legacy. It’s really hard to learn when you skip class, especially on a regular basis, and professors want you to learn and succeed. So go to class. Learn the material. Become a better more informed human.

No they don’t. Sometimes some professors are very cooperative and understand how they should treat their students to make friendly teaching environment, but some professors just want to come and give their lecture and don’t pay attention on students. SO answer is 50/50.

As an undergraduate at UCLA, the lectures by professors were very large and smaller lectures were led by teaching assistants who seemed to care more than professors. Attendance was not based on attendance so much as grades and as a result, one attended lectures if that would help with grades (in terms of information provided).

Yeah, they do. They wanna see people engaged in what they’re teaching. It matters to them if people are not there/asleep vs people actively listening, asking questions, interested. After all, they’re just humans who have dedicated their life to a field of study. It matters to them how students react to their class. (Although you’ll always find the professors who half-ass their jobs and teach just so they can get funding for their research)

I could safely say that all college professors care if you show up in class. The government only grants financial aid to students who attend classes on a regular basis. If students fail to show up in class the college lose funding. I don't know of any college that could operate on zero funding. The college professors salary is also based on student enrollment. Colleges are a business. Like all businesses they need money to operate.

Some do, some don’t. Kinda like students. Some care that they need to show up to class because they’re important to them, others not so much because they don’t view them as important as other things that they’re doing right now. From my experience, those who do care are because there are marks attached to your presence in class (compared to lectures where they don’t care at all and the majority are absent in the middle of the semester)

In my opinion: Generally yes. They want their students to learn the materials they are teaching. They would often take pride in their teaching abilities even though they are required to spend lots of time to bring in grant money.If you are not showing up to class except to take tests, they would wonder how sincere you are as a student.
This professor not only cares as great deal if his students “show up to class”, but is also obligated by policy to record and report attendance.

I think of my students as adults. It’s their responsibility to learn. I will support them in their learning to the best of my ability, but if they are not willing to at least show up, there’s not much I can do about it. Of course I prefer that they show up, that they show up prepared, and that they participate actively.

Contrary to at least one other answer here, most classes tend to be small enough at most colleges [not mega-universities like Cal or Berkeley] that the instuctor can tell if one or a few are missing. Often they have a miss number or a scale for absences. My college deliberately kept sections to 30-or-fewer students, and if people were missing it was evident. If many were missing, it did affect the quality of the lecture. So faculty tended to insist that you attend.
Not usually, they are not paid for you to pass the class only to present the material. In college you are treated as an adult, the decision to attend or not attend is up to you.
Absolutely, especially in classes where participation counts for achievement - languages, for example, or seminar-type classes where if you are not there you are not part of the discussion.
Absolutely! Some professors fail students for missing more than six classes. Also, why pay to go to school if you aren’t going to take advantage of the learning opportunities.

When I was in college, there were some that did take attendance and some didn’t. (Your attendance was graded if they did) I’m not suggesting skipping classes but realized something. The professors that took attendance; taught out of the book. (And studying from books vs notes “worked” on tests) Those that didn’t take attendance created their own lecture, using the book as a guide, but test answers were more from lectures and notes.

Some do, and some don’t. I’m choosing to see “care” as, “Will they fail me if I do not attend regularly”. I had professors who made it clear that if we could pass the exams and turned in the assignments, they would not fail us for not coming to class regularly. I had others who were sticklers for attendance.

Yes and no. Sometimes attendance is taken and carries a bit of grade weight attached to it. But it’s more like “does ___ know the material?” Sure, the instructor often hopes students attend and derive something out of the lectures. Yet no one is going to fall to pieces if you miss a class (unless quiz taken that day perhaps). On the syllabus, you’ll see a range of opinions.
We prefer you come to class, but it’s your choice. If you choose to skip don’t cry about notes or not knowing what is going on in class. I don’t fail you. You fail yourself.

Although professors can make up their own policy, it behooves a student to attend classes, read all the books and articles, do the homework assignments, establish a rapport with the professors, seek tutoring and join study groups in order to have a good chance not just to succeed but to excel. Remember that many professors grade on curves and that in many schools, the competition is fierce.

I would not require attendance but kept it so that if you asked/begged for extra help at near the end of the semester but had not attended class regularly, I would not be of much assistance to you. If you had attended class regularly you would receive as much help as I could manage.

Yes, they do. And make it known to them you are present. Get to know them they’re are human too. They like knowing their students. Sometimes it makes a difference between a B or C… The more they see you and get to know you the more they will help you.

Some undergraduate classes have 10 points for class participation. Since the classes have 25 to 30 students and it is hard to remember individual participation, professors may use the class attendance record for class participation portion. If someone averaged 99 in the three term tests but came late to the class and registered only 2 days’ attendance out of 15 lectures, the best the person can get is B. So attending classes and coming on time is a must.
Some do and some don’t. I think students should care that they attend class. A seat in a college class is costing them a lot of money. Much of the payment is from student loans they have taken out.
In general, no. Some students are highly entertaining and fun to be around, so I do hope that they show up to class. But that’s for my own personal selfish reasons.

No but this is why I always talked to them at the end of the lecture. Tried to email about questions i have. I always tried to be engaged because otherwise you are a number. They care when YOU care. Show initiative and they will help. Bob Smith,

Of course they do! Professors don’t like to teach to an empty classroom. I suppose there maybe subjects in which students may learn by reading books. In language classes, however, practicing the language is essential to acquire proficiency.
You’re big boys and girls; I am not your mom. Show up or don’t. However, missed attendance points could cause a lower grade. Your choice.
Most do. Some don't, but those are the ones most likely to bring in something that wasn't in the syllabus or a great guest speaker or a test.

Well that depends on the class, and the prof. For my intro to behavioural neuroscience course I don’t care. It’s a big class, and there aren’t any participation marks. For a fourth year seminar? Hell yes, then I care. Part of the class dynamic in that case is participation.

Do you? You can calculate the cost per hour. But in general - yes. Even in large classes, I notice students who look interested and participate. If it’s under 40 students I always know. And a class with fewer than 15 doesn’t work if more than one person is absent.
Depends on the class. Large lecture with 400 students, probably not. Smaller class capped at 25 students, probably yes. Your prof will let you know.
Good ones do, because they know the synergistic energy of engaged students improves classroom learning. Can't get that when students don't show up!
Six unexcused absences at the University of Minnesota and you automatically flunk the course. A big part of life is just showing up.
If you’re a star student, yes. If you’re a failing student, no. Just as students love the classes they do well in, teachers love the students who do well.
Generally no. College students are usually 18 and over. That is being an adult and they figure that as an adult you should know that class attendance is important.
even though universities insist on some minimum attendance, educators do not think it is useful at all. we dont want to see heads in class, but participation in class ongoings.
Yes they do—if you are late too many times they will ask you to drop, because you have an obligation to show up to the lectures.
Some care a lot, others do not. Smaller classes get more individual attention than huge lectures.
When you have 100 students in a class, the prof cares less. Some profs do not even want the student to talk with them.

I never had to teach those massive 200+ student classes. I had a simple algorithm when it came to final grades. If you were a borderline case and I couldn’t place your face, then you got the lower grade.
It depends upon the professor. Some actually require it. In general it is best to attend all classes. There is more to learn there than is in the assigned readings.
SOME DON’T, SOME DO, BUT WE CAN’T KNOW THE LATTER’S MOTIVES FOR CARING ABOUT IT
Depends on the college professor: Check the syllabus or ask.
Absolutely not
No
